#Text=CHAPTER XXIV
#Text=On the morning of the twenty-sixth Duane rode into Bradford in time to catch the early train .
#Text=His wounds did not seriously incapacitate him .
#Text=Longstreth was with him .
#Text=And Miss Longstreth and Ruth Herbert would not be left behind .
#Text=They were all leaving Fairdale for ever .
#Text=Longstreth had turned over the whole of his property to Morton , who was to divide it as he and his comrades believed just .
#Text=Duane had left Fairdale with his party by night , passed through Sanderson in the early hours of dawn , and reached Bradford as he had planned .
#Text=That fateful morning found Duane outwardly calm , but inwardly he was in a tumult .
#Text=He wanted to rush to Val Verde .
#Text=Would Captain MacNelly be there with his rangers , as Duane had planned for them to be ?
#Text=Memory of that tawny Poggin returned with strange passion .
#Text=Duane had borne hours and weeks and months of waiting , had endured the long hours of the outlaw , but now he had no patience .
#Text=The whistle of the train made him leap .
#Text=It was a fast train , yet the ride seemed slow .
#Text=Duane , disliking to face Longstreth and the passengers in the car , changed his seat to one behind his prisoner .
#Text=They had seldom spoken .
#Text=Longstreth sat with bowed head , deep in thought .
#Text=The girls sat in a seat near by and were pale but composed .
#Text=Occasionally the train halted briefly at a station .
#Text=The latter half of that ride Duane had observed a wagon-road running parallel with the railroad , sometimes right alongside , at others near or far away .
#Text=When the train was about twenty miles from Val Verde Duane espied a dark group of horsemen trotting eastward .
#Text=His blood beat like a hammer at his temples .
#Text=The gang !
#Text=He thought he recognized the tawny Poggin and felt a strange inward contraction .
#Text=He thought he recognized the clean-cut Blossom Kane , the black-bearded giant Boldt , the red-faced Panhandle Smith , and Fletcher .
#Text=There was another man strange to him .
#Text=Was that Knell ?
#Text=No !
#Text=it could not have been Knell .
#Text=Duane leaned over the seat and touched Longstreth on the shoulder .
#Text=“ Look ! ” he whispered .
#Text=Cheseldine was stiff .
#Text=He had already seen .
#Text=The train flashed by ; the outlaw gang receded out of range of sight .
#Text=“ Did you notice Knell was n't with them ? ” whispered Duane .
#Text=Duane did not speak to Longstreth again till the train stopped at Val Verde .
#Text=They got off the car , and the girls followed as naturally as ordinary travelers .
#Text=The station was a good deal larger than that at Bradford , and there was considerable action and bustle incident to the arrival of the train .
#Text=Duane 's sweeping gaze searched faces , rested upon a man who seemed familiar .
#Text=This fellow 's look , too , was that of one who knew Duane , but was waiting for a sign , a cue .
#Text=Then Duane recognized him -- MacNelly , clean-shaven .
#Text=Without mustache he appeared different , younger .
#Text=When MacNelly saw that Duane intended to greet him , to meet him , he hurried forward .
#Text=A keen light flashed from his eyes .
#Text=He was glad , eager , yet suppressing himself , and the glances he sent back and forth from Duane to Longstreth were questioning , doubtful .
#Text=Certainly Longstreth did not look the part of an outlaw .
#Text=“ Duane !
#Text=Lord , I 'm glad to see you , ” was the Captain 's greeting .
#Text=Then at closer look into Duane 's face his warmth fled -- something he saw there checked his enthusiasm , or at least its utterance .
#Text=“ MacNelly , shake hand with Cheseldine , ” said Duane , low-voiced .
#Text=The ranger captain stood dumb , motionless .
#Text=But he saw Longstreth 's instant action , and awkwardly he reached for the outstretched hand .
#Text=“ Any of your men down here ? ” queried Duane , sharply .
#Text=“ No. They 're up-town . ”
#Text=“ Come .
#Text=MacNelly , you walk with him .
#Text=We 've ladies in the party .
#Text=I 'll come behind with them . ”
#Text=They set off up-town .
#Text=Longstreth walked as if he were with friends on the way to dinner .
#Text=The girls were mute .
#Text=MacNelly walked like a man in a trance .
#Text=There was not a word spoken in four blocks .
#Text=Presently Duane espied a stone building on a corner of the broad street .
#Text=There was a big sign , “ Rancher 's Bank . ”
#Text=“ There 's the hotel , ” said MacNelly .
#Text=“ Some of my men are there .
#Text=We 've scattered around . ”
#Text=They crossed the street , went through office and lobby , and then Duane asked MacNelly to take them to a private room .
#Text=Without a word the Captain complied .
#Text=When they were all inside Duane closed the door , and , drawing a deep breath as if of relief , he faced them calmly .
#Text=“ Miss Longstreth , you and Miss Ruth try to make yourselves comfortable now , ” he said .
#Text=“ And do n't be distressed . ”
#Text=Then he turned to his captain .
#Text=“ MacNelly , this girl is the daughter of the man I 've brought to you , and this one is his niece . ”
#Text=Then Duane briefly related Longstreth 's story , and , though he did not spare the rustler chief , he was generous .
#Text=“ When I went after Longstreth , ” concluded Duane , “ it was either to kill him or offer him freedom on conditions .
#Text=So I chose the latter for his daughter 's sake .
#Text=He has already disposed of all his property .
#Text=I believe he 'll live up to the conditions .
#Text=He 's to leave Texas never to return .
#Text=The name Cheseldine has been a mystery , and now it 'll fade . ”
#Text=A few moments later Duane followed MacNelly to a large room , like a hall , and here were men reading and smoking .
#Text=Duane knew them -- rangers !
